The company raised prices on about a quarter of its U.S. products in July due to higher costs from President Donald Trump’s tariffs, while also enhancing product features.
P&G maintains full-year earnings guidance of $6.83 to $7.09 per share and sales growth guidance of 1% to 5% for the fiscal year, with analysts expecting $6.97 per share in earnings.
The broader context includes U.S.-Canada trade tensions, as President Donald Trump ended all trade negotiations with Canada over a television ad, affecting cross-border trade dynamics.

articles.title: Trump Approves Disaster Declarations for Alaska, North Dakota, Nebraska, and Leech Lake Band of Ojibwe Amid Partisan Divide and Criticism Over Delays
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: President Donald Trump approved major disaster declarations for Alaska, Nebraska, North Dakota, and the Leech Lake Band of Ojibwe following severe weather events, including storms and flooding, while denying requests from Maryland, Vermont, and Illinois. The decisions reflect a clear partisan divide, with Trump approving aid for states and tribal nations he has won in past elections. In Alaska, he granted a 100% federal cost share for 90 days to support recovery. The Leech Lake Band received both public and individual assistance after a June storm caused extensive tree damage, having previously spent $1.5 million of its own funds. Critics, including Maryland Governor Wes Moore and Vermont’s emergency management director, argue that the delays and denials politicize disaster relief and leave vulnerable communities without timely financial support. Trump’s administration has taken longer to process disaster requests than any previous administration, and officials assert that the process ensures efficient use of federal funds. However, the delays and inconsistent decisions raise concerns about equity, transparency, and the impact on affected populations.
keyTakeAways: President Donald Trump approved major disaster declarations for Alaska, Nebraska, North Dakota, and the Leech Lake Band of Ojibwe, citing extensive damage from storms and flooding.

Trump denied disaster declarations for Maryland, Vermont, Illinois, and an Alaska request for public safety building reconstruction, raising concerns about political bias and delays in emergency response.
The decisions show a clear partisan divide, with Trump supporting states he has won in past elections (like Alaska and Missouri) and denying requests from Democratic-leaning states.
The disaster approvals included both public infrastructure assistance and individual aid for survivors, with Trump offering a 100% cost share for 90 days in Alaska.
States and tribal nations face significant financial strain due to delays, with the Leech Lake Band reportedly spending $1.5 million in reserve funds before receiving federal aid.
Critics argue that Trump's extended review process politicizes disaster relief, undermines state-led recovery efforts, and leaves vulnerable communities without timely support.
An Associated Press analysis notes that Trump has taken longer to approve disaster declarations than any previous administration, including his first term.

articles.title: Tropical Storm Melissa Threatens Haiti, Jamaica, and Dominican Republic with Catastrophic Flooding and Hurricane Force Winds
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: Tropical Storm Melissa, a nearly stationary storm in the Caribbean, is expected to strengthen into a major hurricane by Saturday and reach Category 4 status by Monday. It poses severe threats to Haiti, Jamaica, and the Dominican Republic, with forecasts of catastrophic flash flooding, landslides, and up to 20 inches of rain in vulnerable areas. At least three people have died in Haiti due to landslides and flooding, and over 650 emergency shelters have been activated in Jamaica. Residents across all affected regions are preparing through evacuations, securing homes, and stockpiling supplies. The slow movement of the storm—expected to persist for up to 72 hours—has raised concerns of a humanitarian disaster, with officials from Jamaica, Haiti, and the Dominican Republic issuing warnings, closing schools and government offices, and mobilizing emergency responses. The storm is the 13th named storm of the 2025 Atlantic season, with forecasts indicating prolonged exposure and widespread damage across the region.
keyTakeAways: Tropical Storm Melissa is nearly stationary in the Caribbean, moving slowly east-southeast at 2 mph, with a high risk of strengthening into a major hurricane.
The storm is expected to bring catastrophic flash flooding and landslides to southwestern Haiti and southern Jamaica and the Dominican Republic.
Up to 20 inches of rain is forecast for parts of southwest Haiti and east Jamaica, with up to 12 inches in other regions, leading to saturated ground and heightened disaster risk.
At least three people have been killed in Haiti due to landslides and flooding, with the death toll rising from an initial incident involving a fallen tree and flooding in central Haiti.
Jamaica has issued a hurricane watch and tropical storm warnings, with schools, government offices, and airports closing in anticipation of severe conditions.
Over 650 emergency shelters have been activated in Jamaica, and the Bahamian government has evacuated students from Jamaica ahead of the storm.
In the Dominican Republic, nearly 200 homes have been damaged, over half a million customers lost water, and public schools and offices closed in 12 provinces.
The storm is being described as a 'slow-motion disaster' due to its stationary nature and prolonged exposure of vulnerable populations to extreme weather.
Residents in affected areas are preparing by securing homes, moving vehicles to higher ground, and stockpiling supplies, highlighting the severity of the threat.
The U.S. National Hurricane Center and AccuWeather experts warn of a potential humanitarian crisis due to the storm's slow movement and widespread flooding.

articles.title: Wall Street climbs to the cusp of records as oil prices jump
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: U.S. stock markets surged toward record highs on Thursday following President Donald Trump's announcement of massive sanctions on Russia’s oil sector, targeting Rosneft and Lukoil. This prompted a 5.5% jump in crude oil prices, boosting energy stocks such as Exxon Mobil, ConocoPhillips, and Diamondback Energy. Strong earnings reports from companies like Dow, Las Vegas Sands, and Tesla contributed to market gains, while Molina Healthcare and IBM faced declines due to underperformance. Gold prices rose as investors sought safety amid rising U.S. government debt and inflation concerns. Meanwhile, global markets showed mixed performance, with gains in Hong Kong and Shanghai and losses in Japan and South Korea. The article underscores how geopolitical tensions, corporate earnings, and macroeconomic indicators collectively shape global financial markets.

Energy stocks like Exxon Mobil, ConocoPhillips, and Diamondback Energy saw strong gains, with up to 3.4% increases.

IBM fell 0.9% despite solid profit and revenue results, due to underperformance in its Red Hat open-source software segment.
Gold prices rose 2% to $4,145.60 per ounce, reversing a recent decline, driven by concerns over U.S. and global government debt (over $38 trillion) and inflation.
The 10-year Treasury yield rose to 4.00%, reflecting market expectations of potential future rate cuts by the Federal Reserve if inflation remains benign.
Stock markets in Europe rose, while Japan’s Nikkei 225 and South Korea’s Kospi declined, reflecting regional market divergences.
The Chinese Communist Party’s leadership meeting concluded with a focus on technological self-reliance, influencing investor sentiment in Asian markets.

articles.title: Social Security COLA to Rise 2.8% in 2026 Amid Financial and Political Concerns
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: The Social Security Administration has announced a 2.8% cost-of-living adjustment (COLA) for 2026, increasing benefits for nearly 71 million retirees and disabled beneficiaries, with Supplemental Security Income recipients receiving increases by December 31. The adjustment, financed by payroll taxes with a rising cap of $184,500 in 2026, reflects moderating inflation following a record 8.7% increase in 2023. However, public opinion, as shown in AARP polling, reveals that 77% of Americans over 50 believe a 3% COLA is insufficient to keep up with rising prices, and personal testimonies like that of 80-year-old Linda Deas highlight real-world financial struggles. The announcement comes amid political controversy, including claims from former Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent about privatization and statements by Social Security Commissioner Frank Bisignano denying any plan to raise the retirement age. Despite recent reforms by both the Trump and Biden administrations — such as repealing the Windfall Elimination Provision and Government Pension Offset — the program faces a looming financial crisis, with trust funds projected to be unable to pay full benefits starting in 2034. Experts emphasize that COLAs alone are not a solution and call for broader, long-term reforms to ensure financial security for older Americans.
keyTakeAways: The 2026 Social Security cost-of-living adjustment (COLA) is set at 2.8%, increasing monthly benefits by more than $56 for retirees and SSI recipients.
The COLA is financed by payroll taxes, with the annual salary cap for tax collection increasing to $184,500 in 2026 from $176,100 in 2025.
Only 22% of Americans over age 50 believe a 3% COLA is sufficient to keep up with rising prices, while 77% disagree, indicating widespread concern among seniors about affordability.
AARP data and personal testimonies (e.g., Linda Deas) show that even with COLAs, many seniors face difficulty covering basic expenses like rent, food, and auto insurance.

The Social Security Administration has faced political scrutiny, including claims of privatization and potential retirement age increases, which have been denied by officials like Commissioner Frank Bisignano.

Recent policy changes by both the Trump and Biden administrations — including repealing the Windfall Elimination Provision and Government Pension Offset — have improved benefits for 2.8 million former public workers.
The program’s trust funds are projected to be insolvent by 2034, necessitating long-term reform or funding solutions before full benefit cuts occur.
Experts like Emerson Sprick emphasize that COLAs alone cannot solve broader financial challenges for seniors and call for structural reforms.

articles.title: Alabama Executes Anthony Boyd by Nitrogen Gas After 30-Year Legal Battle
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: Anthony Boyd, a 54-year-old man from Atmore, Alabama, was executed by nitrogen gas on October 23, 2025, after being convicted in 1993 of helping to burn Gregory Huguley to death over a $200 drug debt. The execution, which lasted longer than previous nitrogen gas procedures and involved prolonged breathing and movement, sparked controversy over whether the method is humane or constitutional. Boyd, who had been on death row since 1995 and served as a chair of an anti-death penalty group, expressed his innocence and criticized the criminal justice system during his final moments. Religious figures and legal experts raised concerns about consciousness and pain during the process, with Justice Sonia Sotomayor and fellow justices issuing a dissent arguing that nitrogen gas execution violates constitutional rights to dignity and humane treatment. The U.S. Supreme Court declined to intervene, affirming Alabama’s authority to carry out the execution, though the case continues to fuel national debate over capital punishment and its methods.
keyTakeAways: Anthony Boyd, a 54-year-old man from Atmore, Alabama, was executed by nitrogen gas on October 23, 2025, after being convicted in 1993 of helping to burn Gregory Huguley alive over a $200 drug debt.

The execution method, nitrogen gas, was introduced in Alabama in 2024 and has been used in eight executions (seven in Alabama and one in Louisiana), raising national concerns about its constitutionality and human dignity.
Boyd’s final statements expressed innocence and criticized the criminal justice system, stating 'I didn’t kill anybody' and calling for systemic reform.

The execution reportedly lasted longer than previous nitrogen gas executions, with Boyd showing signs of movement and breathing for over 15 minutes, prompting criticism from religious figures and legal experts.

A federal judge denied Boyd’s request to halt the execution, and the U.S. Supreme Court declined to intervene, with Justice Sonia Sotomayor issuing a dissent arguing that nitrogen gas execution is unconstitutional and violates the dignity of human beings.

Boyd had been a chair of Project Hope to Abolish the Death Penalty, an anti-death penalty group composed of individuals on death row, indicating a personal and ideological opposition to capital punishment.

The state maintained that observed movements during execution are involuntary due to oxygen deprivation, while Boyd’s spiritual adviser, Rev. Jeff Hood, claimed consciousness persisted for at least 16 minutes and criticized the method as 'incompetent' and 'painful'.

articles.title: U.S. Criticizes Israeli West Bank Annexation Vote; Gaza Reconstruction and Humanitarian Aid Challenges Grow
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: U.S. Vice President JD Vance condemned a narrow parliamentary vote in Israel to symbolically annex parts of the West Bank, calling it an 'insult' and contrary to U.S. policy under former President Donald Trump. The vote, which passed with 25-24 in the Knesset, is seen as a political provocation aimed at Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, who opposes the move. The international community, including Egypt, Qatar, and Saudi Arabia, denounced the vote as a violation of international law. Meanwhile, the U.S. is advancing a plan to rebuild Gaza in 'Hamas-free' zones, with reconstruction expected to take two to three years and cost approximately $53 billion. Humanitarian conditions remain dire in Gaza, with widespread destruction, lack of medical care, and limited aid access due to only two open crossings. U.S. officials like Marco Rubio have established a civilian-military coordination center in Israel to support stabilization, while international agencies like the WHO and UNFPA emphasize urgent medical and logistical needs.
keyTakeAways: U.S. Vice President JD Vance criticized Israel’s symbolic parliamentary vote to annex parts of the West Bank, calling it an 'insult' and stating it contradicts the Trump administration's policy against annexation.
The vote in Israel’s Knesset passed with a narrow 25-24 majority but is unlikely to become law due to lack of support in the full 120-seat parliament and Netanyahu’s ability to delay or block it.
The international community, including Egypt, Qatar, and Saudi Arabia, condemned the annexation vote, asserting that Israeli settlements in the West Bank violate international law.
The U.S. has expressed support for a two-state solution and is planning to rebuild Gaza in 'Hamas-free' areas, with reconstruction expected to take two to three years and cost around $53 billion.

Humanitarian challenges persist in Gaza, with 80% of pre-war buildings damaged or destroyed, over 15,000 patients needing medical care, and only two aid crossings open, leading to severe aid shortages.
U.S. officials, including Marco Rubio, have opened a civilian-military coordination center in southern Israel to support stabilization and reconstruction in Gaza.
Palestinian officials and international organizations, including the WHO and UNFPA, emphasize the urgent need for medical care, aid delivery, and long-term recovery efforts.
Analysts argue that de facto annexation of West Bank settlements is already underway, despite no formal law supporting it, highlighting deepening tensions in the Israeli-Palestinian conflict.

articles.title: U.S. Stocks Head for Records After Less Painful Inflation Report
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: U.S. stock markets surged toward record highs on Friday following a less painful inflation report, which eased concerns about rising prices and boosted expectations that the Federal Reserve will cut interest rates at upcoming meetings. The S&P 500 rose 1%, the Dow gained 1.1%, and the Nasdaq climbed 1.3%. Strong quarterly profits from companies like Ford, Intel, and Procter & Gamble contributed to the rally, while AI-driven demand is fueling growth in tech stocks such as Google and Nvidia. However, market concerns remain about overvalued gold prices, the U.S. national debt exceeding $38 trillion, and inflation expectations. The article notes that while geopolitical tensions and market volatility from past events like Trump’s tariff threats have created uncertainty, the current positive economic data and strong corporate performance are driving investor confidence. A meeting between President Trump and Chinese President Xi Jinping next week may further stabilize global markets.
keyTakeAways: U.S. stocks rose to record levels following a less painful inflation report, with the S&P 500 up 1% and the Dow up 1.1%.
The Federal Reserve is expected to cut interest rates at upcoming meetings, including one next week, due to improved labor market conditions and inflation expectations.
AI-driven demand is boosting tech stocks: Intel, Google (Alphabet), and Nvidia are benefiting from AI growth, with Google’s parent company seeing a 3.1% rise due to Anthropic’s expansion.
Profitability remains strong across major U.S. companies: Ford, Procter & Gamble, and Intel all exceeded analyst expectations.
Gold prices have surged significantly, with Newmont Mining's stock up 139% year-to-date, raising concerns about overvaluation and inflationary risks.
The U.S. national debt has surpassed $38 trillion, increasing inflationary fears and economic uncertainty.
Consumer inflation expectations remain mixed, as per the University of Michigan report, indicating potential for inflationary feedback loops.
Stocks rebounded after earlier volatility due to criticism over valuation and risk-taking, especially following concerns from President Donald Trump about China tariffs.

Title: Thousands evacuate Philippine coast as Tropical Storm Fengshen approaches

Thousands of residents of a Philippine island have fled their homes along the Pacific coast as weather experts warned of coastal flooding ahead of the approach of Tropical Storm Fengshen, rescue officials said.

The eye of the storm was forecast to brush past Catanduanes, an impoverished island of 270,000 people, later on Saturday with gusts of up to 80km/h (50mph).

Fengshen will bring heavy rainfall, along with a “minimal to moderate risk” of coastal flooding from 1.2-metre (3.2-foot) waves being pushed ashore, the government weather service said.

More than 9,000 residents of Catanduanes moved to safer ground, the provincial disaster office said, in an often-repeated drill on the island that has previously been the first major landmass hit by cyclones that form in the western Pacific Ocean.

The Catanduanes provincial government ordered local officials to “activate their respective evacuation plans” for residents of “high-risk areas”, including the coast, low-lying communities and landslide-prone slopes, rescue official Gerry Rubio told the AFP news agency.

The Philippines is hit by an average of 20 storms and typhoons each year, striking disaster-prone areas where millions of impoverished people live.

Scientists warn that storms are becoming more powerful as the planet warms due to human-driven climate change.

Fengshen comes as the country is still reeling from a series of major earthquakes and typhoons that killed dozens of people in recent weeks.

Earlier this month, at least 79 people were killed in a  magnitude 6.9 earthquake  in Cebu province in the central Philippines.

Days later,  another earthquake  struck, this time a magnitude 7.4 off the coast of the southern Philippines, killing at least six people and triggering a second, magnitude 6.9 quake later in the day. Tsunami warnings were issued after each earthquake.

In late September, several people were killed and thousands were evacuated from villages and schools in the northern Philippines, while offices were closed, as Typhoon Ragasa struck.

articles.title: Pakistan launches its first hyperspectral satellite
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: Pakistan has successfully launched its first hyperspectral satellite, H1, from China’s Jiuquan Satellite Launch Centre, marking a major milestone in its space programme. The satellite, capable of detecting subtle material changes on Earth’s surface, will enhance national capabilities in precision agriculture, environmental monitoring, urban planning, and disaster management. This development is part of Pakistan’s broader push to grow its space technology and is seen as a key component of its strategic partnership with China, particularly in supporting infrastructure projects like the China-Pakistan Economic Corridor (CPEC). While H1 will require about two months of calibration before full operation, it follows the success of two other operational satellites (EO-1 and KS-1), highlighting a significant advancement in Pakistan’s space capabilities.

The satellite's data will support precision agriculture, climate resilience, and efficient management of natural resources.
The launch reflects Pakistan's strategic partnership with China, particularly in peaceful space exploration and shared development goals like the China-Pakistan Economic Corridor (CPEC).
Two other satellites—EO-1 and KS-1—are already fully operational in orbit; H1 is expected to be fully operational within about two months after launch.

Title: Pakistan launches its first hyperspectral satellite

Pakistan has sent its first-ever hyperspectral satellite into orbit, a “major milestone” it says will help advance national objectives from agriculture to urban planning.

The country’s space agency, SUPARCO, announced the “successful launch” of the H1 satellite from northwestern China’s Jiuquan Satellite Launch Centre on Sunday.

Hyperspectral satellites can detect subtle chemical or material changes on the ground that traditional satellites cannot, making them especially useful for things like tracking crop quality, water resources or damage from natural disasters.

Pakistan’s Ministry of Foreign Affairs said the technology is expected to “significantly enhance national capacities” in fields like precision agriculture, environmental monitoring, urban planning and disaster management.

It said its ability to pinpoint geohazard risks will also contribute to development initiatives such as the China-Pakistan Economic Corridor (CPEC), which  seeks to build infrastructure linking  China’s northwestern Xinjiang province with Pakistan’s Gwadar Port.

“The data from the Hyperspectral Satellite is poised to revolutionise agricultural productivity, bolster climate resilience, and enable optimised management of the country’s vital natural resources,” SUPARCO chairman Muhammad Yousuf Khan was quoted as saying in Pakistan’s Dawn newspaper.

Pakistan also hailed H1’s deployment as a “pivotal step forward” in its space programme, as well as a reflection of its longstanding partnership with China in the “peaceful exploration of space”.

articles.title: Trump torpedoes international deal to reduce shipping emissions
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: The International Maritime Organization (IMO) has delayed the formal adoption of its Net Zero Framework (NZF)—a global plan to reduce shipping emissions—by at least 12 months after U.S. President Donald Trump threatened sanctions on countries supporting the measure. The NZF, which would have introduced a $380-per-metric-ton carbon tax on shipping emissions and incentivized cleaner fuels, was originally approved in April 2025. Trump’s public backlash on Truth Social, calling the plan a 'Global Green New Scam Tax,' prompted a vote to postpone the decision, with 57 votes in favor of delay and 49 against. Key supporters including China, the EU, Britain, and Brazil remain committed, while Russia and Saudi Arabia oppose it. Industry leaders and climate advocates, including Vanuatu’s climate minister and the International Chamber of Shipping, have criticized the delay as a setback to urgent decarbonization, especially given growing climate-related threats to maritime safety and the shipping sector’s role in global emissions. The decision reflects a broader geopolitical tension between climate action and fossil fuel interests, particularly in the U.S. and among oil-dependent nations.

Trump publicly criticized the IMO's plan, calling it a 'Global Green New Scam Tax on Shipping' and threatened sanctions on countries supporting the emission regulations.

The decision to delay the framework, which would have established the first global carbon-pricing system for shipping (penalty of $380 per metric tonne of CO2-equivalent), undermines global progress toward net-zero shipping emissions.
The framework aims to reduce international shipping emissions by 20% by 2030 and eliminate them by 2050, aligning with broader climate change mitigation goals.
Countries like China, the EU, Britain, and Brazil reaffirmed their support, while Russia and Saudi Arabia opposed, reflecting geopolitical divisions on climate policy.

The delay has been criticized by climate officials and industry representatives, including Vanuatu’s climate minister and the International Chamber of Shipping, as a setback to urgent decarbonization efforts.
The shipping industry faces increasing climate-related risks, such as altered ocean currents and severe storms, making emission reductions critical for safety and sustainability.

Title: Trump torpedoes international deal to reduce shipping emissions

Members of the International Maritime Organization (IMO) have voted to postpone approving a plan to curb shipping emissions, after United States President Donald Trump threatened to impose sanctions on countries that supported the measure.

The vote on Friday set back plans to regulate the shipping industry’s contributions to climate change by at least 12 months, even though the Net Zero Framework (NZF) had already been approved by members of the London-based IMO, a United Nations body,  in April .

The decision to formally delay adopting the framework until late next year came a day after President Trump took to his Truth Social platform, saying: “I am outraged that the International Maritime Organization is voting in London this week to pass a global Carbon Tax.”

“The United States will NOT stand for this Global Green New Scam Tax on Shipping,” he said, telling countries to vote against the plan.

Washington also threatened to impose sanctions, visa restrictions and port levies on countries that supported the deal.

In advance of this week’s meeting in London, about 63 IMO members who had voted for the plan in April were expected to maintain their support for curbs on emissions, and others were expected to join the initiative to formally approve the framework.

Following Trump’s social media threat, delegates in London instead voted on a hastily arranged resolution to push back proceedings on the matter, which passed by 57 votes to 49.

The IMO, which comprises 176 member countries, is responsible for regulating the safety and security of international shipping and preventing pollution on the high seas.

Since returning to power in January, Trump has focused on reversing Washington’s course on climate change, encouraging fossil fuel use by deregulation, cutting funding for  clean energy projects  and promising businesses to  “drill, baby drill”.

A spokesman for UN chief Antonio Guterres called Friday’s decisions “a missed opportunity for member states to place the shipping sector on a clear, credible path towards net zero emissions”.

The International Chamber of Shipping, representing more than 80 percent of the world’s fleet, also expressed disappointment.

“Industry needs clarity to be able to make the investments needed to decarbonise the maritime sector,” the chamber’s Secretary-General Thomas Kazakos said in a statement.

Disappointed, but still very much Committed!  https://t.co/7P192kAvCx

— Thomas A. Kazakos (@ThomasKazakos)  October 17, 2025

Ralph Regenvanu, the minister for climate change for Vanuatu, said the decision to delay the vote by 12 months was “unacceptable given the urgency we face in light of accelerating climate change”.

“But we know that we have  international law  on our side and will continue to fight for our people and the planet,” Regenvanu added.

Leading up to Friday’s decision, China, the European Union, Brazil, Britain and several other members of the IMO had reaffirmed their support.

Countries that opposed the measures included  Russia  and Saudi Arabia.

A Russian delegate described the proceedings as “chaos” as he addressed the plenary on Friday after talks had lasted into the early hours.

Argentina and Singapore, two countries that had previously voted in support of the framework in April, were among those that voted to postpone introducing it this week.

If it had been formally adopted this week, the Net Zero Framework (NZF) would have been the first global carbon-pricing system, charging ships a penalty of $380 per metric tonne on every extra tonne of CO2-equivalent they emit while rewarding vessels that reduce their emissions by using alternatives.

The framework plan is intended to help the IMO reach its target of cutting net emissions from international shipping by 20 percent by 2030 and eliminating them by 2050.

Climate change is already beginning to affect shipping and the safety of seafarers, including by changing  ocean currents  and causing more frequent and  severe storms .

Proposals to reduce reliance on dirtier bunker fuel in the shipping industry include using ammonia and methanol, as well as fitting cargo ships with special sails.

articles.title: Climate study finds overheating world will add 57 superhot days a year
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: A new study by World Weather Attribution and Climate Central finds that climate change is increasing dangerous 'superhot days' — defined as warmer than 90% of historical days — with the world now expected to experience 57 such days annually by 2100 under current emissions. This represents a significant reduction from the 114 superhot days projected under pre-Paris warming scenarios, but still indicates a major threat to global health and stability. The study highlights a stark inequality in climate impacts: small, ocean-dependent nations like Panama, the Solomon Islands, and Samoa face massive increases in heat exposure — with Panama projected to see 149 additional superhot days — despite contributing just 1% of global emissions. In contrast, major emitters such as the United States, China, and India face only 23–30 extra days. Experts warn that this disparity could deepen global inequities and fuel geopolitical instability, with tens of thousands or millions of people affected by increasingly frequent and deadly heat events.
keyTakeAways: Climate change is increasing the number of 'superhot days' — days warmer than 90% of comparable days from 1991 to 2020 — with the world now expected to see 57 such days annually by 2100.
The Paris Climate Agreement has reduced projected warming from 4°C to 2.6°C, cutting the number of superhot days from 114 to 57 per year, although a significant increase remains.
Since 2015, the planet has already added 11 average superhot days, indicating that climate impacts are already occurring and worsening.

The impact of climate change is highly unequal: small, ocean-dependent nations like Panama, the Solomon Islands, and Samoa face massive increases in heat exposure (e.g., Panama projected at 149 extra superhot days), despite contributing only 1% of global emissions.
In contrast, top carbon polluters — the United States, China, and India — are expected to see only 23–30 extra superhot days despite being responsible for 42% of global CO₂ emissions.
The disproportionate impact of climate change across nations may deepen global inequities and contribute to geopolitical instability.
Experts emphasize that tens of thousands or millions of people will be affected by these heat events, with thousands already dying in heatwaves annually.

Title: Climate study finds overheating world will add 57 superhot days a year

A new study by World Weather Attribution and United States-based Climate Central has calculated the increase in dangerous “superhot days” – defined as warmer than 90 percent of comparable days between 1991 and 2020 – due to climate change.

The report, which is not yet peer-reviewed but uses established techniques for climate attribution, was released on Thursday. It highlights the significant effect of the  Paris Climate Agreement .

Before the 2015 accord, the world was on track for a catastrophic 4C (7.2F) of warming by the end of the century, which would have resulted in an additional 114 superhot days per year.

By fulfilling current commitments to curb emissions, the world is now heading towards 2.6C (4.7F) of warming. Under this scenario, the Earth will still add 57 superhot days annually by 2100 – nearly two months of dangerously high temperatures – but this is half the increase of the worst-case scenario. Since 2015, the world has already added 11 superhot days on average.

Potsdam Climate Institute Director Johan Rockstrom, who was not part of the research team, said people should not be relieved that we are no longer on the 4-degree warming pre-Paris trajectory because the current track “would still imply a disastrous future for billions of humans on Earth”.

The report does not say how many people will be affected by the additional dangerously hot days, but coauthor Friederike Otto of Imperial College London said “it will definitely be tens of thousands or millions, not less”. She noted that thousands die in heatwaves each year already.

The study also underscores the profound unfairness of the impact of climate change across the world, showing a massive disconnect between carbon pollution and expected heat exposure.

The 10 countries that will experience the biggest increase in dangerous heat days are almost all small, ocean-dependent nations like Panama, the Solomon Islands, and Samoa. These countries are expected to see the largest spikes, with Panama projected to face 149 extra superhot days a year. These 10 nations collectively produce only 1 percent of global heat-trapping gases.

In stark contrast, the top carbon-polluting countries – the United States, China, and India – are predicted to get only between 23 and 30 extra superhot days. Despite being responsible for 42 percent of the world’s carbon dioxide, they will face less than 1 percent of the additional superhot days.

University of Victoria climate scientist Andrew Weaver, who was not part of the study team, said this heat inequality drives “yet another wedge between have and have-not nations”, potentially sowing seeds of geopolitical instability.

articles.title: Why has Dutch government taken control of China-owned chipmaker Nexperia?
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: The Dutch government has taken effective control of the Chinese-owned semiconductor company Nexperia under the Goods Availability Act, citing serious managerial shortcomings under former CEO Zhang Xuezheng and concerns over threats to European technological and economic security. This intervention follows a broader geopolitical context of escalating tensions between China and Western nations, including the US, over semiconductor technology and rare-earth metal exports. The Dutch government claims the move ensures the continuity of critical technological capabilities, while China and Wingtech argue it is politically motivated and based on geopolitical bias. As a result, key decisions at Nexperia are now restricted, and the company has suspended Zhang and appointed Stegan Tilger as interim CEO. The European Union has pledged coordination with the Netherlands to safeguard Europe’s technological future in this high-stakes environment.
keyTakeAways: The Dutch government took control of Nexperia, a semiconductor manufacturer, under the Goods Availability Act due to concerns over serious managerial shortcomings and threats to European technological security.

The intervention was prompted by allegations of poor leadership under former CEO Zhang Xuezheng and the broader geopolitical context of China’s export controls on rare-earth metals and the US’s tightening of semiconductor export restrictions.

Nexperia is a global semiconductor manufacturer headquartered in Nijmegen, Netherlands, with operations in Europe, Asia, and the US, and a significant manufacturing capacity producing over 50 billion components annually.
Wingtech Technology, a Chinese-owned group, acquired Nexperia in 2018 for $3.63 billion and is now under scrutiny due to its ownership by a Chinese entity and associated geopolitical tensions.
The Dutch government blocked key decisions at Nexperia for one year, including asset relocations, executive firings, or major operational changes, to protect critical technological capabilities.
Nexperia suspended Zhang Xuezheng as CEO and appointed Stegan Tilger as interim CEO, citing the same managerial shortcomings that led to the government intervention.
China responded to the Dutch action by asserting that the move is politically motivated and based on geopolitical bias rather than a genuine security risk.
The European Union has committed to coordinating with the Netherlands to safeguard critical tech capabilities in Europe, indicating a broader strategic response to the situation.

Published: 2025-10-14T13:37:55+00:00

Title: Why has Dutch government taken control of China-owned chipmaker Nexperia?

The Dutch government has intervened to take effective control of technology group Nexperia, which is owned by Chinese group Wingtech Technology.

The decision comes amid a growing rift between China and the West over the development of technology such as computer chips and semiconductors, which are essential components for the manufacture of artificial intelligence (AI) technology.

Here is more about what the Dutch government announced, why and what happens next.

In a statement released on Sunday, the Dutch Ministry of Economic Affairs said it had invoked the “highly exceptional” Goods Availability Act to intervene and take control of Nexperia on September 30.

The Goods Availability Act allows the Netherlands to intervene in privately owned companies in exceptional circumstances, such as if the government perceives a threat to the country’s economic security or if it is necessary to ensure that critical goods remain available.

The move followed an emergency hearing by the Dutch Enterprise Chamber on October 7, which concluded that there may be “valid reasons to doubt sound management at Nexperia under the leadership of former CEO Zhang Xuezheng”, a statement from the company said.

The Dutch Enterprise Chamber is a special division of the Amsterdam Court of Appeal, which hears corporate law cases and other matters that could have major social or financial consequences.

In its statement, the government said the intervention had been carried out “due to serious administrative shortcomings” at Nexperia, which “posed a threat to the continuity and safeguarding on Dutch and European soil of crucial technological knowledge and capabilities”.

It claimed that the intervention would ensure Nexperia’s finished and semi-finished products would remain available in case of an emergency.

The ministry added that “losing these capabilities could pose a risk to Dutch and European economic security.”

Following this intervention, it said, “the company’s regular production process can continue.”

However, it added, “Based on the order, decisions within the company can be blocked or reversed if they are (potentially) harmful to the company’s interests, its future as a Dutch and European company, and/or the preservation of this crucial value chain for Europe.”

The statement said that “involved parties” can appeal the decision in court.

Nexperia is a global semiconductor manufacturer headquartered in Nijmegen, the Netherlands. It emerged as a result of electronics group Philips’ purchase of London-based Mullard Radio Valve Company and Hamburg-based Valvo in the 1920s, ultimately forming Philips’ semiconductor operation. In 2006, Philips spun off its semiconductor division, which became NXP Semiconductors, and this was later sold to a consortium of investors led by Beijing Jianguang Asset Management (JAC Capital). Wingtech acquired Nexperia from that consortium for $3.63bn in 2018.

According to its website, Nexperia employs 12,500 people in Europe, Asia and the United States.

Nexperia’s manufacturing site spans more than 80,000 square metres (861,000dsq feet) and has the capacity to build more than 50 billion components annually. It also has sales offices and research-and-development sites in China.

On Tuesday, Nexperia announced that it had suspended Zhang, founder of Wingtech, as a director and removed him as chief executive officer (CEO). It has appointed Stegan Tilger, chief financial officer (CFO), as interim CEO.

“Due to the same serious managerial shortcomings, the Dutch Ministry of Economic Affairs observed that Nexperia’s operations in Europe were being compromised in an unacceptable manner. This situation raised broader concerns for the Dutch government about the availability of semiconductor products critical to the European industry,” Nexperia’s statement said.

“The combination of Zhang Xuezheng’s behaviour as CEO and (indirect) shareholder, as well as concerns about the semiconductor product availability in the Netherlands and Europe, ultimately led the Dutch government to intervene with an exceptional emergency order on the basis of the Goods Availability Act.”

The statement added that the government’s order has also prohibited Nexperia from relocating company assets, firing existing executives or making important decisions without explicit government approval for one year.

Nexperia said it is confident its daily operations will continue as usual.

On October 9, China  tightened export controls  for critical rare-earth metals, citing national security interests. Foreign companies must now obtain approval from Beijing before they can export the named rare-earth metals or any products that contain them. Exporters must tell the government how the products will be used.

The US is a major consumer of Chinese rare-earth metals, which are critical for its defence industry. Following China’s announcement about new export restrictions, US President Donald Trump responded by  threatening to impose a new 100 percent trade tariff  on China.

Besides being used for the manufacture of smartphones, electric cars and weapons, rare-earth metals are also used in the manufacture of semiconductors, which are essential for the development of artificial intelligence (AI) technology.

The US and its Western allies in Europe have, in recent years, passed regulations restricting China’s access to Western semiconductor technology, fearing that China could reverse-engineer and manufacture the technology, moving ahead in the technological race.

In 2022, former Democratic US President Joe Biden  restricted China’s access  to US semiconductors. The new rules extended restrictions on chipmaking tools being sold to industries which support the semiconductor supply chain. They blocked these industries from accessing US technical expertise, as well as the key components required to build the machines that produce microchips.

The US further tightened these restrictions in October 2023 and, again, in December 2024.

On September 29, 2025, the US Bureau of Industry and Security extended US export control restrictions to all groups which are at least 50 percent-owned by one or more entities on the US Entity List, a list of foreign organisations and companies believed to be participating in, or are at significant risk of participating in, activities that go against US national security or foreign policy interests. These entities are subject to sanctions, export restrictions or licensing requirements. While Nexperia itself is not on the list, Wingtech was added in December 2024.

Then, on October 4, China’s Ministry of Commerce announced export controls preventing Nexperia China and its subcontractors from exporting certain finished components and sub-assemblies made in China.

“Nexperia is actively engaging with the Chinese authorities to obtain an exemption from these restrictions and has deployed all available resources to that end,” the Nexperia statement said.

“While Nexperia has made sufficient preparations to ensure business continuity – and as the BIS rule provides for a 60-day grace period – we are confident that a solution will be found,” Nexperia said in its statement on Tuesday.

Compounding all this, earlier in the year, US President Donald Trump imposed tariffs of 145 percent on Chinese imports to the US. China retaliated with a tariff of 125 percent on US goods. Both countries then reduced their tariffs for 90 days in  May  to allow for trade talks. In August, the two agreed to another 90-day pause, with the most recent round of talks taking place between US and Chinese officials in Spain last month.

But the US has also imposed restrictions on most Chinese cars from being sold in the US. These include high tariffs on Chinese-made electric vehicles.

In addition to its standard 10 percent car import duty, the EU announced last year that it would impose a range of additional tariffs on electric vehicles, from 7.8 percent for Tesla vehicles to 35.3 percent on China’s state-owned SAIC [Shanghai Automotive Industry Corporation] vehicles.

Wingtech released a social media statement saying it “firmly opposes the politicisation of commercial matters”.

In the post, it deemed the Dutch government’s move “an excessive intervention based on geopolitical bias rather than a fact-based risk assessment” that is based on the “unfounded pretext of national security”.

Shares in Wingtech have plummeted by 10 percent on the Shanghai Stock Exchange since the announcement. As a result, Wingtech was forced to explain the situation to the exchange, saying that the Dutch government’s decision “temporarily restricts” its control over Nexperia.

Beijing “consistently opposes the overstretching of national security concepts and discriminatory practices targeting companies from specific countries”, Lin Jian, spokesperson for the Chinese Ministry of Foreign Affairs, said on Monday.

“Relevant countries should genuinely uphold market principles and avoid politicising economic and trade issues.”

The European Union has been closely coordinating with Dutch officials and will now work with the Netherlands to decide what to do next to protect important tech capabilities in Europe, according to European Commission spokesperson Olof Gill.

articles.title: Five dead, two missing as Tropical Storm Fengshen soaks Philippines
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: Tropical Storm Fengshen swept through the Philippines in October 2025, causing at least five deaths and two people missing. In Quezon province, a tree fell on a bamboo house in Pitogo, killing five family members including two children, with a teenage boy surviving. Flooding in Luzon and Samar, along with a landslide in Mindanao’s Bukidnon province, forced over 47,000 people to evacuate, and five dams released water to mitigate flood risks. The storm coincided with recovery efforts from recent earthquakes, prompting Philippine President Ferdinand Marcos Jr. to stress the need for improved disaster preparedness. Experts also link the storm’s intensity to broader climate change trends, which are making extreme weather events more severe.
keyTakeAways: Tropical Storm Fengshen caused significant loss of life and displacement in the Philippines, with at least five deaths and two people missing.
The storm triggered deadly flooding and landslides, particularly in Luzon and Mindanao, with a family of five killed in Quezon province when a tree fell on their bamboo house.
At least 47,000 people evacuated to temporary shelters, and five dams on Luzon released water to reduce flood risks.
A teenage boy survived the tree-fall incident in Pitogo, Quezon, becoming the only survivor of the family tragedy.
In Mindanao, a landslide on the Bukidnon highway caused two people to go missing, with the road now blocked.
The storm coincided with recovery efforts after a recent series of earthquakes that killed at least 87 people.
Philippine President Ferdinand Marcos Jr. emphasized the need to strengthen disaster preparedness due to the country’s high vulnerability to natural disasters.
Scientists warn that extreme weather events like storm Fengshen are intensifying due to climate change, with the Philippines experiencing about 20 storms per year.

Title: Five dead, two missing as Tropical Storm Fengshen soaks Philippines

At least five people have been killed and two reported missing as  Tropical Storm Fengshen  sweeps through the Philippines, triggering heavy flooding on the main island of Luzon and a vast landslide on the southern island of Mindanao.

In Quezon province in the north of the country, five members of one family, including two children, were crushed to death when a tree fell on their bamboo house early on Sunday, according to Philippine disaster agency officials in the town of Pitogo, where the incident took place.

Images posted on social media by officials showed the house destroyed under the weight of a large palm tree, as a rescue team worked to remove the bodies of the family.

According to a statement shared on social media, a teenage boy was the lone survivor of the accident in Pitogo, about 153km (95 miles) southeast of the capital Manila.

More than a dozen flights were ordered cancelled by aviation authorities as Fengshen hovered over Luzon, situated just south of Manila, as of Sunday afternoon. The storm was reported to be moving west towards the South China Sea.

The AFP news agency quoted officials in southeastern Luzon as saying at least 47,000 people had left their homes for the safety of government-designated temporary shelters since Saturday. At least five dams on Luzon island opened their gates to release water on Sunday, according to the national weather agency, Pagasa.

In the central Philippines, heavy flooding was reported by officials on the islands of Samar and Panay, forcing residents to evacuate.

One person was injured in the town of Estancia on Panay Island after he was pinned down following the collapse of his wooden house, the ABS-CBN news website reported.

Rumagasa ang baha sa ilang barangay sa Calbayog City, Samar dahil sa hagupit ng bagyong  #RamilPH  sa lugar ngayong Linggo, October 19. | via Ranulfo Docdocan

(Courtesy: Reymark Espinosa)  pic.twitter.com/dJAV5eOdZo

— ABS-CBN News (@ABSCBNNews)  October 19, 2025

Translation: Raging floodwater inundated several areas of Calbayog City in Samar due to Tropical Storm Ramil [Fengshen] as of Sunday, October 19.

In the province of Bukidnon on the southern island of Mindanao, two people were reported missing after their motorised three-wheel vehicle fell off a highway following a large landslide triggered by the heavy rains.

Public works officials said the highway, which connects Bukidnon to the neighbouring Davao region, is now blocked to traffic.

On average, the Philippines is hit by about 20 storms and typhoons each year, and scientists warn that extreme weather events are becoming more powerful as the planet warms due to human-driven climate change.

Fengshen also comes as the Philippines started to recover from  a series of major earthquakes  that killed at least 87 people over the past three weeks.

In a Facebook post published on Sunday, Philippine President Ferdinand Marcos Jr said the country needs to “strengthen its disaster preparedness and response” as it is “very prone to having disasters and calamities”.

articles.title: China tightens export controls on rare-earth metals: Why this matters
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: China has tightened its export controls on 12 of the 17 rare-earth metals, including five new additions, and restricted specialized refining equipment, with the new measures set to take effect on December 1, 2025. The restrictions target products with at least 0.1% heavy rare-earth content, requiring foreign companies to justify their intended use. China justifies the move on national security grounds, citing transfers of controlled materials to military or sensitive applications. The US is the largest importer of Chinese rare-earth products, relying on these materials for critical defence systems like F-35 jets, submarines, and missiles, as well as civilian technologies such as electric vehicles and AI systems. This action is seen as a strategic move ahead of a high-level Trump-Xi meeting during the APEC summit in South Korea, signaling China’s intent to leverage its dominant supply position in the rare-earth market to strengthen its diplomatic and economic leverage in ongoing US-China trade negotiations.
keyTakeAways: China has expanded its export controls on rare-earth metals, now restricting 12 out of 17 total rare-earth elements — including five new additions (holmium, erbium, thulium, europium, ytterbium) and seven previously restricted metals (samarium, gadolinium, terbium, dysprosium, lutetium, scandium, yttrium).

The restrictions apply to both raw rare-earth materials and specialized refining equipment used in processing, requiring foreign companies to obtain special Beijing approvals and justify the intended use of products, especially those with at least 0.1% heavy rare-earth content.
China cites national security and international non-proliferation concerns, citing instances of foreign entities transferring or processing Chinese rare-earth materials for military applications.

Rare-earth metals are vital for key US defence systems (e.g., F-35 jets, submarines, missiles) and civilian technologies (e.g., electric vehicles, AI chips, LED displays, medical equipment), making the controls strategically impactful.
The US is the largest importer of Chinese rare-earth products, having imported $22.8 million worth in 2023, with 70% of its imports from China between 2020 and 2023.
China is the world’s largest producer and processor of rare-earth metals, mining at least 60% and processing about 90% of global supply, giving it significant leverage in global supply chains.
The move is seen as a strategic signal ahead of the Trump-Xi meeting during the APEC summit in South Korea, suggesting China is using its supply dominance as leverage in trade negotiations.
The controls are not absolute — exemptions exist for emergency medical needs, public health emergencies, and disaster relief, preserving some essential global supply flow.
Analysts interpret this as a 'signalling' manoeuvre to strengthen China’s negotiating position, potentially deepening the US defence and industrial vulnerability as global tensions rise.

Title: China tightens export controls on rare-earth metals: Why this matters

China tightened export controls for critical rare-earth metals on Thursday.

The new restrictions, announced by the Ministry of Commerce, come in advance of an expected meeting between United States President Donald Trump and his Chinese counterpart, Xi Jinping, later this month.

The world’s two largest economies have been locked in trade negotiations aimed at calming tensions, after their tit-for-tat tariffs against each other earlier this year, before agreeing to pull back some of those duties.

Rare-earth metals are one of China’s major levers of influence with the US.

In “announcement number 61 of 2025”, China said it was increasing export controls for five rare-earth metals in addition to the  seven it announced in April this year .

The five metals added to the list are holmium, erbium, thulium, europium and ytterbium.

The seven minerals China placed export restrictions on earlier this year are samarium, gadolinium, terbium, dysprosium, lutetium, scandium and yttrium.

There are 17 rare-earth metals in total – the 15 lanthanides (metallic elements) on the periodic table, as well as scandium and yttrium. China now has export restrictions on 12 of them.

Additionally, China also placed restrictions on the export of specialist technological equipment used to refine rare-earth metals on Thursday. Most of these restrictions will come into effect on December 1.

The announcement means that foreign companies will need to obtain special approvals from Beijing if they wish to export rare-earth magnets and certain semiconductor materials that have at least 0.1 percent heavy rare-earth metals from China.

To obtain the licence, foreign companies must explain the intended use of the product they wish to make using Chinese rare-earth metals.

China cited national security interests as the reason for these new restrictions.

“Rare-earth-related items have dual-use properties for both civilian and military applications. Implementing export controls on them is an international practice,” a Chinese Commerce Ministry spokesperson told reporters.

The spokesperson added that “certain” foreign organisations and individuals have been directly transferring – or processing and then transferring – controlled rare-earth materials originating from China to “relevant organisations and individuals directly or indirectly for military and other sensitive applications”.

“This has caused significant damage or posed potential threats to China’s national security and interests, adversely affected international peace and stability, and hindered global non-proliferation efforts.”

Rare-earth metals are essential for the production of technological equipment such as electric cars, lithium-ion batteries, LED televisions and camera lenses.

The metals are crucial for the US defence industry. According to the Center for Strategic and International Studies (CSIS) think tank, rare earths are used to manufacture components of F-35 fighter jets, Virginia and Columbia-class submarines, Tomahawk missiles, radar systems, Predator unmanned aerial vehicles and the Joint Direct Attack Munition series of smart bombs.

Additionally, rare earths are used to create semiconductors, which are used in artificial intelligence (AI) technology.

This is a strategic move on the part of China, analysts say.

China is the largest producer of these rare-earth metals. It mines at least 60 percent and processes about 90 percent of the world’s rare-earth metals, CSIS reported in 2024.

The new restrictions have been announced just three weeks before Trump visits South Korea to attend the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) summit in late October.

During his visit, Trump is expected to meet Xi. The leaders last met in person in 2019.

Earlier this year, Trump imposed tariffs of 145 percent on Chinese imports to the US. China retaliated with 125 percent tariffs. After reducing their tariffs to 30 percent and 10 percent, respectively, in May, the two sides struck a truce in August, agreeing on a 90-day pause to allow time for trade talks. That pause has since been renewed twice as talks continue – most recently between US and Chinese officials in Spain last month.

China’s new restrictions on rare-earth metals, which Trump is known to want badly, give it more leverage for these talks.

Gracelin Baskaran, director of the CSIS Critical Minerals Security Program, explained that the US defence industry is facing significant challenges caused by its limited production ability to meet rising defence technology needs. By restricting exports, China may be able to accelerate the expansion of its military strength at a faster pace than the US.

“The new restrictions will only deepen these vulnerabilities, further widening the capability gap,” Baskaran said.

“The move both strengthens Beijing’s leverage in upcoming talks while also undercutting US efforts to bolster its industrial base at a time where Indo-Pacific tension is climbing,” she said.

“Most [restrictions] don’t go into effect until December 1, 2025, leaving close to 2.5 months for these negotiations.”

The Chinese Commerce Ministry spokesperson told reporters on Thursday: “China is willing to strengthen communication and cooperation through bilateral and multilateral export control dialogue mechanisms, promote compliant trade, and ensure the security and stability of global industrial and supply chains.”

Kristin Vekasi, the Mansfield chair of Japan and Indo-Pacific Affairs at the University of Montana, said Beijing’s latest moves are about leverage. She said this is a part of “pre-meeting choreography” before Trump’s meeting with Xi during the APEC summit in South Korea.

“China hasn’t yet pulled the trigger on export restrictions, but it’s reminding Washington that it could. This move signals that Beijing is willing to weaponise its dominant position in the rare earths supply chain, especially as both governments prepare for a potential Trump-Xi meeting at APEC. It’s a classic signalling manoeuvre designed to strengthen China’s negotiating hand.”

The US will be especially hit hard. In 2023, it was the largest importer of Chinese rare-earth minerals and products, importing $22.8m worth of products from China, according to the Observatory of Economic Complexity (OEC). In total, China exported $117m in rare-earth metals and products that year.

The US sourced 70 percent of its rare-earth compounds and metals imports from China between 2020 and 2023, according to a US Geological Survey report.

“On the defence side, we’re talking about inputs for fighter jets, missile guidance systems, and more. On the civilian side, everything from smartphones and medical imaging equipment to electric vehicles depends on rare earth magnets. In other words, this isn’t just about defence but touches the everyday technologies that enable our modern life,” Vekasi said.

Hong Kong ($12.1m), Russia ($12.2m) and Japan ($9.42m) also import significant amounts.

The US restricted China’s access to its semiconductors in 2022 under the administration of Democratic former President Joe Biden. Some US lawmakers have pushed for greater restrictions, warning that China could reverse-engineer or independently develop advanced semiconductor technologies, overtaking the US in the industry and securing a military advantage.

“China’s move shows it can make life very difficult for US manufacturers – but doing so would also hurt its own economy, since many of these supply chains run both ways. It’s a reminder that the US-China economic relationship isn’t a clean decoupling story; the two markets are still very much intertwined,” Vekasi from the University of Montana said.

Yes.

The Commerce Ministry spokesperson said exports pertaining to emergency medical needs, in response to public health emergencies or for disaster relief, will be exempt from the restrictions.

articles.title: Is your beef linked to Amazon deforestation? A report highlights loopholes
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: Human Rights Watch has released a report exposing how JBS, the world’s largest meat company, may be contributing to illegal deforestation in Brazil’s Amazon through its supply chain. The report reveals that cattle raised in protected areas of Pará—such as the Cachoeira Seca Indigenous Territory and Terra Nossa sustainable development zone—are moved through an untraceable 'laundering' system, where animal transit permits (GTAs) record only group-level data, making it impossible to track individual animal origins. Despite JBS’s 2009 promise to trace all indirect suppliers, it has not fulfilled this commitment, and its 2026 goal to require supplier declarations lacks enforcement. The Brazilian state agency Adepará has authorized cattle transport into protected zones, enabling illegal ranching. Experts and advocacy groups argue that only a federal, publicly accessible traceability system can stop deforestation, warning that current timelines—such as the 2026 Pará decree and 2032 federal mandate—are too slow. The findings are particularly urgent as the report is published just before COP30, the UN climate summit in Pará, emphasizing the global stakes of corporate responsibility in environmental degradation.
keyTakeAways: JBS, the world’s largest meat company, is allegedly sourcing beef from cattle raised in illegally deforested areas of Brazil’s Amazon, specifically in Pará, via untraceable supply chains.
Human Rights Watch found that cattle are moved through a 'laundering' system that obscures their origins, allowing illegal ranching activities to go undetected.
Brazil’s current livestock tracking system relies on 'animal transit permits' (GTAs), which only record group-level data (number, sex, age), not individual animal origins.

The state of Pará has seen a 421% increase in deforestation since 2023, with illegal ranchers encroaching on protected areas such as the Cachoeira Seca Indigenous territory and Terra Nossa sustainable development area.
The Brazilian state agency Adepará has authorized cattle movement into protected zones, even though it claims not to monitor environmental compliance, enabling illegal deforestation.
JBS acknowledged in a 2025 SEC filing that it cannot guarantee the legal origin of its cattle due to supply chain loopholes.
JBS committed to requiring supplier declarations by 2026, but there is no clear mechanism for verification or enforcement.
Greenpeace and Human Rights Watch criticize JBS for failing to meet past commitments and call for stronger, enforceable government regulation rather than voluntary corporate action.
Experts suggest that making GTA data publicly accessible would help law enforcement identify fraudulent movements and trace cattle back to illegal ranches.
A federal government-led traceability system is considered the best solution, but implementation is slow and may not stop deforestation in time.

Title: Is your beef linked to Amazon deforestation? A report highlights loopholes

The world’s largest meat company, JBS, has allegedly fuelled illegal deforestation, land grabs and human rights abuses in the Brazilian Amazon by sourcing cattle from ranches operating inside protected areas, according to a new Human Rights Watch investigation.

On Wednesday, the nonprofit issued an 86-page report focusing on the state of Pará, where the United Nations will hold its annual climate change summit, COP30, next month.

The report highlights a gap in JBS’s supply chain: Human Rights Watch claims the meat company does not track its indirect cattle suppliers.

Investigators found that cattle raised on illegally deforested land were moved through a “laundering” system that concealed their origins before they reached JBS.

That, in turn, means JBS cannot guarantee that its beef or leather products are not contributing to deforestation and related abuses.

Without a better system for tracing livestock, JBS will continue to be “unable to root out illegal cattle ranches”, according to Luciana Téllez, a senior environment researcher at Human Rights Watch.

And what JBS does not know could make it responsible for bankrolling illegal ranches that clear-cut the Amazon, she explained.

“We cannot say with 100-percent certainty that the cattle that JBS purchased from its direct suppliers are the same ones that are coming from illegal cattle ranches, but neither can JBS,” Téllez told Al Jazeera.

“That’s a problem, because they are responsible for what they are procuring.”

Wednesday’s report is part of an ever-growing body of literature delving into the impact agriculture has had on the Amazon rainforest.

The construction of ranches and farmland is considered the single biggest direct cause of deforestation in the world’s tropical regions.

The Amazon rainforest is no exception. In recent years, cattle ranching has emerged as a primary culprit in the levelling of its tangled, biodiverse jungles.

The northern state of Pará is key to the fight against further loss. It has consistently recorded the highest levels of deforestation in the Brazilian Amazon since 2016.

In 2024 alone, 17,195 square kilometres (6,639 sq miles) of forest in the state were degraded, a 421-percent increase over the previous year, according to Human Rights Watch.

The state also reports the second-largest number of land conflicts in Brazil, with illegal ranchers, farmers and criminal groups seeking to invade protected land.

For Indigenous and traditional communities that consider the Amazon home, these invasions have been devastating. Residents have seen their crops destroyed, the forest burned, and their lives displaced.

In some cases, community members have even been threatened, attacked or killed after denouncing the land grabs.

Though federal law prohibits such activity, some land-grabbers have succeeded in fraudulently registering protected rainforest as private properties.

Wednesday’s report documented encroachments in two protected areas: the Cachoeira Seca Indigenous territory and the Terra Nossa sustainable development area.

“The level of violence and intimidation by land grabbers in Terra Nossa is truly frightening, and the absolute impunity they’ve enjoyed for years is astonishing,” Tellez told Al Jazeera.

Human Rights Watch said that Pará’s state animal health agency, Adepará, had registered ranches in both tracts of land. It also authorised the transportation of cattle in and out of the two areas.

According to the report, Adepará claimed that it has not historically been tasked with observing environmental criteria when authorising livestock movements.

But with the state agency’s approval, Human Rights Watch said cattle were raised illegally inside the protected rainforest zones and then transferred out to other ranches.

From there, they could reach major slaughterhouses, including JBS facilities.

Each transfer helped obscure the cattle’s illegal origin, effectively laundering the animals into the meat trade.

Part of the problem, according to Human Rights Watch, is Brazil’s system for tracking livestock.

Brazil does not keep full histories of individual animals. Instead, their movements are documented with “animal transit permits”, known as Guias de Trânsito Animal or GTAs.

Those permits collect information about overall shipments of animals: the number of cattle involved, plus data about the sex and the age of those in the group.

But without an individual record for every cow, calf and bull, it is difficult, if not impossible, to trace their origins.

In an April filing to the United States Securities and Exchange Commission, JBS acknowledged the loopholes in how the GTA system traces cattle.

“As a result, there can be no assurance that available monitoring procedures can ensure that the origin of any head of cattle was in full compliance with applicable laws,” JBS wrote.

The company has promised to require its suppliers to declare their suppliers by 2026. Yet, Human Rights Watch says it remains unclear how such information would be verified or enforced.

“The best solution is for the federal government itself to institute a traceability mechanism for cattle across Brazil,” Tellez said. “The Brazilian government is moving towards that, but it’s moving extremely slowly.”

JBS also made a similar commitment more than a decade and a half ago. In 2009, the company signed the G4 Cattle Agreement with environmental group Greenpeace, pledging to identify all its indirect suppliers by 2011. It failed to meet that deadline.

“It’s unacceptable that companies such as JBS have not fulfilled the promises that they made in the past,” Cristiane Mazzetti, a forest campaign coordinator at Greenpeace Brazil, told Al Jazeera.

“It’s something that now governments need to reflect upon and regulate in a more stringent way, because only believing in voluntary corporate commitments is not going to deliver.”

JBS did not respond to Al Jazeera’s request for comment by publication.

But reform may be on the horizon. In 2023, Pará’s governor introduced a decree requiring all animal movements in the state to be fully traceable by the end of 2026.

At the federal level, the Ministry of Agriculture announced a similar plan in December 2024, mandating that all states implement tracking systems by 2032.

However, Human Rights Watch warns that this timeline is too slow and could allow illegal ranching to persist for years.

Experts and advocacy groups say that Brazil should take immediate steps, including by making GTA data publicly accessible. Such measures would help law enforcement agencies identify fraudulent movements and trace cattle back to illegal ranches.

“Companies struggle with traceability, firstly because they have minimal access to public data on the production chain,” said Lisandro Inakake, an agronomist with the Brazilian environmental nonprofit Imaflora.

He added that the struggle is compounded “because there are no universal market requirements covering all of the companies’ operations”.

While Human Rights Watch has called on JBS to voluntarily start tracing the lifespan of its cattle, Mazzetti, the Greenpeace campaigner, believes more decisive action is necessary if deforestation is to be stopped.

“It’s not time for new promises,” she said. “It’s time to be held accountable for all the impacts that their supply chain generated in the Amazon, in other ecosystems, and also on the climate.”

articles.title: UN pushes for worldwide disaster alerts as extreme weather ‘spirals’
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: The United Nations' World Meteorological Organization (WMO) is calling for urgent improvements in global early-warning systems for extreme weather, noting that nearly half of all countries lack adequate monitoring and forecasting capabilities. This leaves millions — particularly in developing nations — vulnerable to deadly weather events, with disaster-related deaths six times higher in countries without warnings. Over 2 million people have died from climate-related hazards in the past 50 years, mostly in developing countries. While progress has been made, with 108 countries now using some form of early-warning systems (up from 52), half still have only basic capacity. The situation is worst in fragile and conflict-affected regions, although progress is being made in Africa. Recent extreme weather events in 2025, including floods in Pakistan, Nigeria, and South Korea, and wildfires in southern Europe and the US, underscore the urgency. A key example is the May 2025 warning of a glacier collapse in Switzerland, which allowed the evacuation of the village of Blatten, demonstrating the real-world effectiveness of early-warning systems.
keyTakeAways: Nearly half of all countries lack effective early-warning systems for extreme weather, leaving millions — especially in developing nations — at high risk.
Disaster-related deaths are six times higher in countries without early-warning systems, highlighting the life-saving potential of such systems.
Over 2 million people have died from weather, water, and climate-related hazards in the past 50 years, with 90% of those deaths occurring in developing countries.
While 108 countries now use some form of multi-hazard early warning systems (up from 52 in the past decade), half still have only basic capacity and 16% have less than basic capacity.
The situation is most dire in fragile, conflict-affected, and violence-prone regions.
Progress is being made in Africa, where more countries are establishing functioning websites and standardizing alerts.
The WMO emphasizes that early warnings lead to early action, and the goal is not just to issue alerts but to empower communities to respond effectively.

Recent extreme weather events in 2025 — including floods in Pakistan, Nigeria, and South Korea, and wildfires in southern Europe and the US — demonstrate the global scale and frequency of climate-related disasters.
The collapse of a Swiss mountain glacier in May 2025 was predicted through monitoring, enabling evacuation of the village of Blatten, showing the practical value of early detection systems.

Title: UN pushes for worldwide disaster alerts as extreme weather ‘spirals’

Nearly half of all countries lack early-warning systems for extreme weather events, leaving millions – especially those in developing nations – vulnerable.

As it released a new report on Monday, the UN’s World Meteorological Organization (WMO) called for gaps in global monitoring and forecasting networks to be plugged. Timely alerts are crucial to saving lives as extreme weather events multiply due to climate change, it warned.

“Many millions of people lack protection against dangerous weather, which is inflicting an increasing toll on economic assets and vital infrastructure,” said a statement by the WMO, noting that disaster-related deaths are six times higher in countries without early-warning systems.

The organisation said weather, water and climate-related hazards have killed more than 2 million people in the past 50 years. It added that 90 percent of those deaths occurred in developing countries.

“Impacts are spiralling as weather becomes more extreme,” it said.

The WMO acknowledged that there has been “huge progress” in climate monitoring over the last decade. The number of countries using some form of multi-hazard early warning systems has jumped from 52 to at least 108.

However, it continued, an assessment of 62 countries showed half of them possess only basic capacity and 16 percent have less than basic capacity.

“The situation is worst in fragile, conflict and violence-affected contexts,” the organisation said.

Nevertheless, the WMO is seeing progress in Africa, with more countries having functioning websites and issuing standardised alerts.

“Early warning means early action. Our goal is to not only warn the world; it is to empower it,” WMO Secretary-General Celeste Saulo said in a speech as the UN institution opened its annual conference in Geneva on Monday.

The world has been rocked by numerous weather-related disasters in 2025. Huge  flooding has rocked countries including Pakistan ,  Nigeria  and  South Korea . Wildfires have devastated large areas in  southern Europe , as well as  the US .

The head of Switzerland’s Federal Department of Home Affairs, Elisabeth Baume-Schneider, told delegates at the conference that no country or region was spared from the effects of climate change and extreme weather.

She pointed to the example of how the regular monitoring of a mountain glacier allowed scientists to warn about its imminent collapse in May 2025, allowing for the evacuation of the Swiss village of Blatten.

“Permafrost melt will inevitably lead to more glacier collapses and rockfalls,” making early warning systems vital, she said.
